content: How can I help you today?

I’ve just been really stressed out lately. Work has been tough, and I’m constantly worried about losing my job. I can't stop thinking about it at night, and it’s making it impossible to sleep. My partner convinced me to come here, but I’m not sure how much this is going to help.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like things have been overwhelming for you lately. Stress about work and losing sleep can really take a toll. It’s also great that your partner cares about you and encouraged you to seek support. What’s been on your mind the most when it comes to work or sleep?

I can’t stop thinking about all the things that could go wrong. The company isn’t doing great, and I feel like I’m on the chopping block if they start laying people off. It’s like when I get into bed at night, my brain won’t shut off, and I keep running through worst-case scenarios over and over.

That sounds really consuming, constantly playing out worst-case scenarios in your mind. It’s no wonder it's hard to get restful sleep with those worries weighing on you. It seems like this situation is bringing up a lot of uncertainty for you. What do you think might help ease some of that mental load, even just a little?

I’m not really sure what would help. I try to tell myself to stop worrying, but it doesn't work. I feel like if I don’t think about it, I’m ignoring the problem, but thinking about it just makes it worse. It’s like I’m stuck in this loop, and I don’t know how to break out of it.

It sounds like you're feeling trapped between trying to stay on top of the problem and the toll it’s taking on your well-being. That loop can feel really frustrating and exhausting. Finding ways to break out of it—even small shifts—could help. What usually helps you relax or feel more in control in other areas of your life?

Honestly, I don’t even know anymore. I used to enjoy reading or watching TV to unwind, but now I just can’t focus on anything because my mind is so wrapped up in these worries. Even spending time with my kids, which I love, sometimes makes me feel more stressed because I keep thinking about what could happen if things go south at work. It’s just hard to relax at all lately.

It sounds like even the things you used to find comforting—reading, TV, time with your kids—feel harder to enjoy because your mind keeps pulling you back to worrying about work. That sounds really heavy and hard to escape from. It’s clear that you care deeply about your family and your own well-being, which says a lot about who you are. What do you think might help you feel even a little calmer or more present for yourself and your loved ones right now?

It’s tough when even the things you normally enjoy lose their ability to help you relax. It’s like the stress just creeps into everything, even the moments that should bring you joy. Maybe finding small ways to give yourself a break from the constant stress, even if it’s just for a few minutes, could be a start. Have you ever tried anything like deep breathing or writing your thoughts down to get them out of your head?

It does sound exhausting when stress takes over everything, even the joyful parts of life. Taking small breaks could be a way to give your mind some relief—I like the ideas you’re exploring. Deep breathing and writing can sometimes help ease mental clutter or create a moment of calm. Do either of those ideas interest you, or is there something else you’d like to try?

I haven’t tried either of those things before. I guess I could give them a shot, though I’m not sure how much they’ll help. It’s worth a try if it’ll help me get out of my head for a little while, I guess.

That’s a great mindset—being open to trying something new, even if you're unsure how much it might help. Sometimes even small steps can make a difference. Would it be helpful to talk about how to get started with one of these strategies, or is there anything else you'd like to focus on right now?

Maybe we could start with something simple, like taking a few moments each day to try some deep breathing. It doesn’t have to be a big thing—just a way to see if it helps calm your thoughts a bit. Or, if writing feels more natural, jotting down whatever’s racing through your head could help lighten the mental load. What do you feel most comfortable starting with?

It’s great that you're open to exploring these options. Deep breathing could be a simple way to start—it’s something you can do anytime and doesn’t take much effort. Writing could also be a way to let those racing thoughts out so they’re not stuck swirling in your head. Which of these feels easiest or most approachable for you right now?

I feel like deep breathing might be easier to start with. It’s simple, and I can try it whenever I start feeling overwhelmed. I’m not sure I’d even know what to write if I tried writing things down, but maybe I could consider it if the breathing doesn’t help.

That sounds like a good approach—starting with something simple like deep breathing and giving yourself space to see how it feels. It’s great that you’re open to trying this. Would you like some general guidance on how to get started with deep breathing, or do you feel ready to give it a try on your own?

That sounds like a good starting point—keeping it simple with deep breathing is a great idea. It doesn't have to be complicated. You could try something as easy as taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose for a count of four, holding it for a moment, and then exhaling through your mouth for the same count. How does that sound to you?

That sounds like a doable and straightforward approach! Slow, deep breathing can sometimes help settle the mind and body, even just for a moment. Trying this breathing pattern could be a calming way to ease tension. How do you feel about making space for this sometime today or when stress starts to build?
Yeah, I think I could try that later today, especially if I start feeling stressed. It’s worth a shot to see if it helps me feel a little more in control. I’ll give it a try and see how it goes.

That’s a great step forward—committing to give it a try and see how it feels. Even small efforts like this can make a difference over time. It’s wonderful to see your willingness to explore something new. Is there anything else on your mind that you’d like to talk through?
